question.title: Indri library java.lang.UnsatisfiedLinkError..change to java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError only on the server

node.contents: I'm asking if in your current project you have a package which name starts with `java` e.g. `java.something.else.here` (regardless the library) and if in that package you have a class called `indri_jndi`.

node.contents: After a fast review on indri, seems that you have to set the `java.library.path` variable when running the project and that variable is not set or there's a problem related to this variable.

astNode.text: After a fast review on indri, seems that you have to set the `java.library.path` variable when running the project and that variable is not set or there's a problem related to this variable.

node.contents: I just found out that indri wont work on linux since it is dependant to som ewindows dlls, I think I should delete this post. Thank you so much for your help.

node.contents: I have this web application where I use the indri.jar in it. I am using eclipse.

astNode.text: I have this web application where I use the indri.jar in it. I am using eclipse.

node.contents: I have put it in the lib folder and did "add to build path" option.

astNode.text: I have put it in the lib folder and did "add to build path" option.

node.contents: Also in "Build Path -> Configure -> Order and Export", everything is checked.

astNode.text: Also in "Build Path -> Configure -> Order and Export", everything is checked.

node.contents: Also in "Properties -> Deployment assembly", all the jar files are added. Then I export the project to .war and put it on the server.

astNode.text: Also in "Properties -> Deployment assembly", all the jar files are added. Then I export the project to .war and put it on the server.

node.contents: I checked the lib folder of the deployed project and the jar file is there.

node.contents: Also my machine and server are both 64 bit, since for this library there are two versions for 32 and 64 bit, and it wont work if you use them instead of each other.

node.contents: It is also important to say that we are a team working on this project using git repository, and when the other side pull the code all the libraries and everything is attached and they have no problem running the code. (They have installed indri, and I did install it on the server)

node.contents:
1. Indri is working on command line on the server, so the problem is not with indri but is with deploying.

  2. When I deploy the code by commenting the lines related to Indri, it works, that shows I am exporting to .war correctly.

astNode.text:
1. Indri is working on command line on the server, so the problem is not with indri but is with deploying.

  2. When I deploy the code by commenting the lines related to Indri, it works, that shows I am exporting to .war correctly.

node.contents: There is an important file in indri installation which is libinrdi_jni.so, which has the role of linking java to c language which is the language the library has been written to. It is located in the indri installation foler: ./install/lib/libindri_jni.so.

astNode.text: There is an important file in indri installation which is libinrdi_jni.so, which has the role of linking java to c language which is the language the library has been written to. It is located in the indri installation foler: ./install/lib/libindri_jni.so.

node.contents: My code couldn't find this file. So I had to put it somewhere in the server that it will definitely look into and then it did find it and everything worked.

astNode.text: My code couldn't find this file. So I had to put it somewhere in the server that it will definitely look into and then it did find it and everything worked.

node.contents: To make sure that you will have this file you need to install indri in this way:

astNode.text: To make sure that you will have this file you need to install indri in this way:

node.contents: ./configure --enable-java --with-javahome=address/to//jdk1.7.0 --prefix=/address/to/indri-5.7/install

astNode.text: ./configure --enable-java --with-javahome=address/to//jdk1.7.0 --prefix=/address/to/indri-5.7/install

node.contents: make all install

astNode.text: make all install

node.contents: make sure to download the jdk1.7 and extract it yourself instead of using any install package. This way the libindri_jni.so will be installed.

astNode.text: make sure to download the jdk1.7 and extract it yourself instead of using any install package. This way the libindri_jni.so will be installed.

node.contents: Then to make sure that your java program will work, you need to run IndexUI.jar, and RetUI.jar, provided in the indri folder. If it works, then your program will work too, but if it is not working, then try running this command:

astNode.text: Then to make sure that your java program will work, you need to run IndexUI.jar, and RetUI.jar, provided in the indri folder. If it works, then your program will work too, but if it is not working, then try running this command:

node.contents: export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/address/to/indri-5.7/install/lib

astNode.text: export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/address/to/indri-5.7/install/lib

node.contents: then run the jar file again, if the problem has been resolved, the libindri_jni.so file is the problem and you can solve it by locate it in a place that program can definitely find it.

astNode.text: then run the jar file again, if the problem has been resolved, the libindri_jni.so file is the problem and you can solve it by locate it in a place that program can definitely find it.
